Everybody has a like a personalized

>> I am I'm happy to jump in. I have a

to go somewhat quickly through them. Um,
but yeah, just to say up front, I I I
don't believe Discover is perfect by any
means. Uh, I think that there's a lot of
ways that we can improve it. It's just
about picking which kind of lanes we
want to focus on at any given time. Um,
one of our biggest challenges like
continues to be scale. Uh, we get so
many islands published into our
ecosystem every day. Um, we're at the
point where it's anywhere between two
and 5,000 different updates or new
islands in the ecosystem um, in a given
like day or week. Um, and it's just
really challenging for us to build in a
kind of algorithmic understanding of all
of that content because going through it
manually just like isn't feasible. And
with the scale that we aspire to shoot
for, it's also like not reasonable for
us to try to set up any type of manual
reviews. I mean, we mean we have
moderation, but I mean like on the
discovery side, it's really hard for us
to play test 5,000 different islands.
Um, and so we need systems in place that
give us a better understanding of what
content we think will be successful with
what players. Um, and I think we try to
look at all content within that like
really positive light of just like
everything has has a spot. Like
everything can be good. everything can
be good for a specific audience and it's
just about kind of like Sax said pairing
that content with those players in a way
um pretty like ideally quickly
effectively like first and foremost the
thing that they are seeing and discover
um so scale is always going to be one of
the things that we come back to it's
just one of our challenges um I think
we've you mentioned it kind of at
earlier like we also want to have some
amount of editorial as well and figuring
out how we kind of go through that
process uh there's a lot of cleanup that

the most exciting content we can find

and in general, I think one of our
biggest challenges is like we're we're
trying to grow the ecosystem. We're
trying to grow the different types of
content we have available for players. a
lot of our audience is still very VR

that sort of like brand image so that
Fortnite feels like an ecosystem. Um,

challenging to get, you know, people who

larger ecosystem that isn't just battle
royale,
>> I think to like to say something like

I guess Fortnite is shooters and we

Yeah, I mean I'm happy to give at least
a part of the answer and I don't want to
speak for the whole there's a whole
separate quests in XP team too and and
they spend a lot of time thinking about
this like uh I don't think we we feel
that XP is is perfect by any means. Um a
lot of our investment for the past 6 to
12 months at this point has really just
been in XP infrastructure. Um, as you
all probably notice, we made a bunch of
XP changes and then a bunch of kind of
bad actors were able to, you know, find
different edge cases and find abuse
vectors or or whatever in ways that
maybe we weren't super happy about. Um,
and a lot of that comes back to the
infrastructure that we had set up for XP
was very much built for one game first
and then uh we tried to kind of copy and

the sort of rubber bands and duct tape
fell off in the middle somewhere uh and
it just resulted in a in a system that

able to report on like outliers, not
able to actually uh you know identify us
when things were being taken advantage
of. Um, and so that's been where a lot
of our investment has been. Um, from my
perspective, I think that XP is still a
really powerful tool for like game
designers in the ecosystem. I think if
you play an experience with just a flat
rate XP, it the experience can feel very
flat versus when you are actually taking
meaningful actions and then you get XP
rewards kind of based on those actions.
I think that's a really powerful
reinforcement tool for like, oh, this
game is fun. I'm liking what I'm doing.
I want to keep coming back to this. Um,
and so I don't want to take that away
from creators just because I do think
it's really powerful. Um, and it's just
about finding the right balance. I know
that like calibration has come up a
bunch in the past as well. Um, even
while we're calibrating, we we do still
like have XP at like some flat rate and
then you kind of move into the
calibrated version based on the
different accolades and everything else
you've gotten set up in your island. Um,
so I I think it's not it's not perfect.
I think we want to clean up uh our
infrastructure and monitoring first and
get us kind of sort of like a good
foundation. Um and then I think we can
start really tackling like okay what's
the right way to allow creators to kind
of build for their experience.
>> Yeah. Guiding principle is that the
creators should have the same ability to
use XP in exciting ways that that we do
when we make or whatever.
>> Um and like the truth is that the like
the XP exploits or whatever like for as
a as a as a percentage of the total XP
granted is like a tiny percentage. Um,
and the
um, and again the good actors that use

in a game that's game related and and

I think when 90 plus% of all play time
is on islands that are calibrated in in
um in creator made content. So it's not
like there's no it's not like it used to
be like it's a lot more distributed like
where XP is earned I guess is what I'm

like rather than the accolades where
it's kind of up and down. Um, we I've

>> I think as a player who wants to explore

players, uh it it bec it's an

Because then their their XP isn't

Like really doesn't work. I don't think

even you played. like um and so I think
like that needs to be resolved and we

is by having better like infrastructure

that's on us to improve and it's

>> like the game design like sort of

>> Cool. Well, thank you for answering

why was search designed to be so exact

squatting dog is misspelled
intentionally so that I could get a

if you were to search squatting dog as
it's formally spelled with two T's, you

like why why wasn't fuzzy search

>> Yeah, Paula, why is that? So,
>> yeah.
Sax, I'm so glad you asked. Um, we we've

um to kind of support new functionality
within it. So, this includes like core
search functionality like semantic
search or creator search, things of that

inputs that allow us to configure like
how we do the actual sorting of results,

Like search should be more than just
exact match. I know exactly what I'm
looking for. I promise to spell it
correctly. Uh and I'm going to get back

There are folks who do that absolutely.
There are also folks who use it as an

uh to see what that looks like. Um,
additionally, I would say that like

Um, so I would expect, you know, changes

uh, is there a time frame that we could

>> Yeah. So like the

>> Awesome. Um, another curiosity a lot of
creators had was like, how do you guys
determine like a specifically made or
trending discovery category? So, like I
use the word trending. It's not always
trending, but like an example would be
like when only up popped off, there's an
Only Up uh uh platform or like tab for

do you guys decide that? Like what what
is and then what is the advantage of of

that look like on Epic's side?
>> Yeah, I'm happy to kind of intro and
Paul, I'm interested in your thoughts,
too. Like um I think it's it's funny
like we try to stay really plugged into
the ecosystem and and kind of keep a a
monitor on like what content is new and
like oh we're starting to see some you
know this type of game show up more
consistently and I think that um
basically that signal turns into these
types of games are finding success.
Maybe there's only a few of them in the
ecosystem. They don't fall cleanly into
our existing categories or buckets. Um,
and it it feels like if someone were to
kind of like want to play more of that
type of game, they wouldn't really know
where to go. And I think once we find
ourselves in a situation like that,
we're like, okay, what we could do very
short term is we can come up with some
criteria that could at least allow us to
identify these types of games. And that
always like isn't always possible
either. Um, but in the example of like,
you know, only up type games, we
actually looked at like basically
Z-axis, like how far up and down players
were traveling vertically in the game.
And that was how we identified games
that were like only up type games or
whatever. Um, and you know, and we've
done basically similar things for for
roganks and farming and whatever other
genres. Um, and a lot of that is like
let's introduce this as a row. let's
like create a space for creators who
want to build this type of experience to
feel like oh this this is where I would
fit into. Um and then at some point we
reach like a critical mass of content
where we can actually start
algorithmically identifying it with like
ML models and and sort of
categorization. Uh and then it becomes a
lot easier to support and sort of scale
into the rest of the ecosystem. Um but
some of the issues is like oh there's
only like two of these types of games
right now. Well we can't just have a row
with only two games in them. So like we
need a little bit of a minimum
threshold. we need to be able to
identify it based on the data from like
players in the game. Um because we can't
just sort of editorially pick them um
unless it's you know for Epics picks or
whatever. Um and so it's a little bit of
like uh a a not super structured
process, but it is based on kind of like
